holidays.name: Groundhog Day
holidays.description: A tradition where a groundhog predicts the weather: if it sees its shadow, six more weeks of winter; if not, an early spring arrives.
holidays.origin: Dating back to ancient European weather lore, brought to America by German immigrants; popularized in Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania.
holidays.funFact: The most famous groundhog, Punxsutawney Phil, has been 'predicting' the weather since 1887!

holidays.name: Bubble Gum Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate bubble gum ‚Äì blowing bubbles, chewing away stress, and enjoying everything about this chewy treat!
holidays.origin: Created by bubble gum enthusiasts to honor its invention and quirky fun nature.
holidays.funFact: Bubble gum was invented in 1928 by Walter Diemer, an accountant who created the first bubble gum that didn't stick to everything.

holidays.name: World Wetlands Day
holidays.description: An environmental observance promoting awareness about the importance of wetlands for biodiversity and ecosystem health.
holidays.origin: Established in 1997 to mark the signing of the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands in 1971.
holidays.funFact: Wetlands cover only 6% of the Earth's surface but support 40% of all species! They're like nature's unsung heroes.

holidays.name: Fettuccine Alfredo Day
holidays.description: The day to celebrate the creamy, cheesy delight of Fettuccine Alfredo, an Italian pasta dish beloved worldwide.
holidays.origin: Inspired by Giuseppe Alfredo invented in Rome in 1914 and popularized to the world thanks to Hollywood stars.
holidays.funFact: Legend says that Hollywood stars Douglas Fairbanks and Mary Pickford loved Alfredo's creamy pasta so much they brought the recipe back to the U.S., making it a sensation!
